author: Капуста

text:
at programming conferences, and educational meetups It's always 90% men. the main reason why it's hard for women is not overwhelming overt sexism, but instead women being intimidated by a culture made up of and around being a man. I'm a highschooler who runs a programming club at our school and I can tell you from experience that it is 10x more difficult to recruit girls than it is to recruit guys, regardless of aptitude for math, problem solving or programming. Guys who show no aptitude for math, or programming, come back club meeting after club meeting while girls who show real promise back out because they that their not smart enough. Showing women that they have no reason to fear programming is super important. 

P.S. I'm a guy, and I'm not advertising anything crazy or drastic I'm just saying when an industry is 90% men you know there is a problem. I recently was fortunate enough to attend mit splash. While I was there I found that all of my CS classes were 90-100%  guys.﻿

author: Unboxing Sve

text:
I know what you mean. I enjoy developing, but in an office environment its risky to do something like, full stack development. Its no longer good enough that you know how to develop and can pass a whiteboard interview. You have to know javascript framework XYZ at its latest revision.

Say that you get the job, its just a large version of Diner Dash at a lot of companies where 1.) nothing is documented 2.) training is discouraged because it takes up precious time being 'productive' 3.) The only devs that understand how the whole system works are your bosses who can use that to their advantage in order to move goal posts on you if they feel like they want to get you to quit. 

Long story short, a career as a fullstack developer is horse-shit unless you work at a smaller company or one of the large tech giants. Getting a development job at large local companies will ultimately lead to burnout, back stabbing, corporate politics, incompetence, and people taking special privileges by abusing their station.﻿

author: David M.

text:
science != engineering

Science uses strict rules (scientific method) to admit measured observations and calculations in order to disprove hypotheses. Academics is not exactly related to science, but the woman seems to be practicing computer science, which is a misnomer.  It's actually computer engineering.  Programming is, more specifically, software engineering.  Engineering is the application of science but it's not science.﻿
author: -tAz-

text:
@Dan McCarthy
There are plenty female role models, it's just that the majority of women don't really care about science and technology to be able to make them more popular. 

It's ok to want to prove that you as a minority group can do the same as the majority of people in that field but then making it seem like the fact that you're a woman deems you more worthy of attention is very offensive and cocky behavior which is actually also sexist.
The fact that you're a woman shouldn't be relevant at all, it's your actions that should be judged and not your sex.

I know they do this to get more women into the field, but think about that for a second..

If they like to do this kind of work, wouldn't they just come for their own reasons, wouldn't that be better motivation than just wanting to prove that women can do this too or just wanting more women work into a field with predominantly male workers..

It seems stupid to entice women into something just because there aren't a lot of women instead of letting them choose by themselves.﻿
author: onlyme0349

text: @-tAz- According to your definition of science, there can both be computer and software science. Software and computers also have a set of rules that come with them. Putting those rules into practice is then called engineering. So what she is doing is both. She is creating rules as well since she's making a framework which is a tool that comes with it's own rules. It's just based on perception.﻿
author: onlyme0349

text: Rules have no relation to engineering. She could be practicing computer engineering in addition to software engineering, but I don't remember any mention of that from when I watched the video over a month ago.  It could be said that certain rules must be followed in order to practice valid science. For example, there are strict rules set forth on how to acquire valid observations. Errors in measurements and calculations must be propagated correctly so that a final probability approaching 1.0 can be attained on the truth of the final outcome.  Computer science does not yield any such probability because the "science" in its name is a misnomer.﻿
author: -tAz-

text:
When programming you are observing while you engineer the systems of the software you develop, sometimes you do it beforehand, errors in measurements and calculations can be propagated correctly when the system you are developing on is well made and "science" (rules and calculation) have been done right. Just like with regular science.

The difference is that the foundation for regular science are the systems that exist in the world instead of having man made systems as a foundation for computer science.﻿
author: onlyme0349

text: Scientific observation is stricter than ordinary observation. It requires meticulous records, repeatability, reproducability, concensus.  It seems inefficient when logic can do. Scientific method would probably be overkill to just gain understanding of a man made system, but I suppose you could, if you really wanted to.﻿

author: FlyingMagneticLizard

text:
So, just in the past 2 weeks, I've written and thrown out about a dozen parsers for a half dozen completely different syntaxes from scratch in C and over the course of the last 4 years have come up with tons of highly experimental ideas for everything from memory management and concurrent data-oriented design to an exceptionless error-handling model enforced by the type system; from a hypothetical implementation of serializable statically-compiled runtime code-generation with static dispatch via type-injection to using version control deltas to identify side-effects of subroutines and using them to dynamically generate instruction tiles for the backend of a compiler. Last week, I invented a new extremely memory efficient representation for unicode strings that's O(log N) indexable.

When I post notes about my work on programming forums; it's completely ignored and I get bitched at for flooding chat boxes. Meanwhile, here's this Harvard student that creates the most useless Python library ever and she gets heralded as the next Alan Turing by MIT Tech Review because she's a woman who can program. I do all of this on my free time. Never been to school for it because I can't afford it. This is about as unfair as life gets people.﻿

at programming conferences, and educational meetups It's always 90% men. the main reason why it's hard for women is not overwhelming overt sexism, but instead women being intimidated by a culture made up of and around being a man. Wow .. the title and content is quite misleading.
She is programming Jeeves. Wich is basicly a python "extension" or framework (Library) to implement her security features.

I respect her effort and what they are doing but they try to make it look like the reinvention of the wheel .. but much better - wich it isn't. So nothing was really said about what and how she is developing and the product itself... just babbling around the topic but never the topic itself ... meta and domain... give me more meaningless buzzwords please..
And this is supposed to be a MIT Technology REVIEW ... where was the tech reviewes ??? please just stop making these "holy grail" type of videos where you try to sell women as any profession ... just tell us what they did the respect comes by itself.

author: spirit469

text:
They refer to this project as embedded language, Library and API. I was claiming that this is not a "from the ground up new language" wich is true. Because it is a embedded Language installed as a library in python communication via their API (correct me if I am wrong).
The video is terrible (we agree on that). They talk little to nothing about the product itself. If the title would have been "This Woman(and Team) Created a EMBEDDED Programming Language with Privacy Baked In" a lot of the comments would look much different. 
They never even mentioned python the very language they DEPEND on. 
She in the video says she is agnostic to the domain and it is about the higher abstract idea and how they want to programm ... wich doesn't sound like a DSL (domain SPECIFIC Language) or does it ?
It sounds like a complete independent programming language.
It is a lot of work to do what she did - but the video needs to be more precise. They create the idea she IS writing a whole new independent language. Of course you can't put every detail in a 2-3minutes video - but that it is a library for python is a key information - missing.﻿

author: Frankey2310

text:
Some Neanderthals in the comment section are right, the title is misleading and most of us came here wondering about the implications of baking in 'privacy' in a programming language and the idea behind it's design and implementation. Creating a DSL/Library for privacy is nothing outside of the ordinary. From the official site:

"Our active implementation of Jeeves is our Python embedding. We allow programmers to use Jeeves simply by importing our JeevesLib library and annotating classes and functions with the @jeeves annotation. You may browse and download the code on GitHub.

We have a preliminary implementation of Jeeves as an embedded domain-specific in Scala. What this means is we have a Scala library that allows you to write Scala-looking code that behaves according to the Jeeves semantics. You may browse and download the code on Google Code.

There is also a Haskell implementation of the symbolic execution semantics for Jeeves."﻿

author: Gerardo Paredes

text: dnifan Not quite. Jeeves does some AST trickery (I think), which means that those access policies are actually enforced and verified automatically: You say what parts of your code should have access to a thing, and Jeeves establishes inviolable constraints. Think of it as like Rust's borrowck, but checking for information permissions, rather than memory access.﻿

author: Joshua Pratt

text:
Joshua Pratt http://projects.csail.mit.edu/jeeves/

From there, you can get the academic papers, and the code and examples off of Github. It pretty much just looks like Python, because the syntax is the same. It is the semantics that have changed.

As for why Python was chosen, it's probably because that's the language the DSL's creator knows best: MIT loves Python.

The other reason is that Python is one of the only languages where you could really do this. The other big languages where it would be possible (and where this sort of thing would be traditionally implemented) are Common Lisp and the Schemes (which would be a kickass name for a rock band).

In fact, 10-15 years ago, I bet this would have been implemented in Scheme, seeing as it came out of academia. Both Common Lisp and most Schemes have facilities that make this sort of thing far easier to implement, and it would probably have been much cleaner as well: Python AST manipulation sucks. However, 6.001 is no more, and so Python it is. :-(﻿
author: Thoth Of The XVth

text:
Josh Barrett hmm. Thanks for the explanation and link.
To me it seems like it's going to be really slow. I was thinking that it could have been implemented in Haskell in a few lines (a wrapper type that can have functors applied but that hides its wrapee and only allows extraction when a specific key is passed in, then functions can be type checked to not be able to unwrap the value but can still perform the allowed operations on it). Then you avoid all those interpretation issues and get static type checking. Also I'd expect someone to call _dict_ on everything and probably find a way to extract values anyway.
Still, kinda cool.﻿
author: Joshua Pratt

text:
Joshua Pratt You actually wouldn't be able to do it in Haskell. Not properly. Reason being, you can't enforce the boundaries you make. Assuming I understand Jeeves' semantics (I think I do, but I may be wrong), your view of the object is restricted, and that restriction is enforced at runtime. If you call __dict__, you should only see the bits of the object you can access, and even if you can see more, your access attempt should be terminated. It's chroot(2) for objects, but actually secure (probably: see the disclaimer about my understanding of the semantics).

You can't force that kind of verification using pure Haskell. Somebody could always bypass your verfication function and access the data directly. Yeah, they're not supposed to, but if someone can, than someone will. You need to bake it into the language itself: you add a call to the function (decorator, whatever), and accesses get verified at compile/runtime. In order to do this, you need to run code at compile time to rewrite the function and add those checks, or otherwise do the verification. So Haskell can't do it.

...But Template Haskell probably can. As can (I think) Forth, and the Lisps (as I mentioned), because Lisp programmers do this sort of thing for fun.﻿
author: Thoth Of The XVth

text: Josh Barrett Surely if all it does is restrict what methods and attributes of objects are accessible from outside the object it's entirely redundant? Sounds the exact same as public Vs private interfaces to objects to me.﻿
author: Magic Balazs

text: Rebellion No, because it restricts access dynamically: Functions (and maybe other objects?) can be granted access to subsections of the object on an individial basis, rather than the all-or-nothing of public vs private.﻿
author: Thoth Of The XVth

text: Josh Barrett As far as OOP goes, that concept isn't best practice... The entire point of the public interface is that you can trust it to return the message you expect. If the objects ability to return the expected message varies depending on what function is being called by what object, you can't fully trust the public interface as you should be able to. Sure, as a concept this does solve privacy issues between objects but at the expense of long term code maintainability, especially considering you will have to redefine what objects can access what interface when you make a change down the line...﻿
author: Magic Balazs

text: Rebellion I'm not sure if I agree. It's usually very simple to determine what parts of an interface should be exposed to a given object for it to do its job properly. If you embedded the annotations for that into the object being restricted, I think it could work quite well.﻿

author: DxBlack

text:
DxBlack And you clearly didn't do your reasearch: http://jeeveslang.org/. Higher up in the thread, I linked the github.

A lot of people are saying that all they see is Python. That's because Jeeves is a DSL (Domain Specific Language) built atop Python. However, it is still a separate language. See the "@jeeves" decorator in the example code they give? That's no ordinary decorator: it's re-writing the AST of your function to use Jeeves primitives (if, function calls, and so on): The result is a language with the same syntax as Python, but different primitives, and therefore different *semantics*: Hence, it's a new language. A DSL, technically, but they likely simplified the title of the video for the unwashed masses.

And if you'd ever used Common Lisp in your damned life (or were otherwise aware of some variant of Lisp or Scheme-style macros), and done about 5 minutes of careful research, then I could have wasted less of my time explaining all this to you.﻿
